title: Only the privileged can afford not to eat on public transport
text:
Banning food on public transport isn’t going to single handedly solve childhood obesity (Picture: Getty Images)

If recent headlines are anything to go by, it’s not long until our freedom to eat on-the-move is over.

Chief Medical Officer, Dame Sally Davies has dominated headlines by suggesting the government should ban all food and drink on public transport, with exceptions for water, breastfeeding and medical conditions.

Even if we ignore the sinister suggestion that only breastfed babies will be allowed to eat on the bus, is this really the bold, radical solution to protect our kids and our population’s health that the headlines suggest?

Spoiler: Of course not.

The real issue is that 30% of new jobs created in the second half of 2018 were filled by those already in work.

Second jobs are part of the reality that the UK population works the longest hours in the EU, with less time to sit down and eat together.

Many Britons work hours outside the traditional nine to five; the number of people working night shifts has risen by five per cent since 2013, meaning one in nine UK employees are night workers.

For many people in lower-income brackets, working longer hours for poor pay is a theme.

If both parents are holding down jobs with unorthodox hours, sitting down together as a family to eat home-cooked food, is often not achievable.

So apart from being impractical to implement, banning food on buses and trains would actually deprive families of opportunities to actually eat.

The idea that people could simply avoid eating on-the-move is reflective of a bias which is becoming more commonplace in conversations around public health policy – privilege.

None of this is new and it’s not the only issue.

The narrative around obesity has always been problematic.

You’d be forgiven, in today’s climate, for believing that high weight was simply a matter of personal responsibility or, in the case of children’s weight, parental responsibility.

Banning food on public transport won’t solve childhood obesity and this report never claimed it would.

By making snacking on public transport an issue, we’re reinforcing the (incorrect) presumption that weight, and health, is something we can all control – that it’s simply a matter of personal responsibility.

This line of thinking is quite convenient for the government yet it does nothing to help the general population who are impacted by poor policies that fail to support them.

The frenzied conversations that are whipped up about these issues create outrage, with an unwavering focus on behaviours as a solution, have created a red herring.

How many times have you heard ‘childhood obesity is child abuse’ or listened to people discussing the failings of parents whose children are higher in weight?

Advertisement

These attitudes are borne of a misunderstanding about weight, which is an outcome – not a behaviour – influenced by a multitude of interlinking factors.

The report contained excellent suggestions for tackling commercial determinants of health which influence our food environment. What it missed was a focus on tackling inequalities – both structural and social.

To improve health we need to be striving for change, that is unquestionable.

But the frenzied conversations that are whipped up about these issues create outrage, with an unwavering focus on behaviours as a solution, have created a red herring.

We need to take action through a variety of avenues, from policy interventions which tackle the structural and social causes of poor health, through to fostering an understanding of the complexity of weight and reducing weight stigma.

All this includes, of course, striving to improve our food environment.

But we need to remember that most barriers to ‘healthy eating’ aren’t due to a lack of education or awareness that on balance, most of us should be eating our vegetables and moving more – they are created by the society and environment we live in.

As noted in Dame Sally’s report, the children living in the most deprived areas are disproportionately affected by poor health and ‘obesity’.

Stopping them snacking on buses probably won’t help with this.

But perhaps – as crazy as it sounds – improving their lives and reducing inequalities will.
